dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, Host_B, so for years, if you talked about a safe haven for investors, like, where did everyone's mind immediately go?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, Host_B, so for years, if you talked about a safe haven for investors, like, where did everyone's mind immediately go?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's easy, right? The U.S. Um, specifically, U.S. Treasury bonds. Full faith and credit, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's easy, right? The U S. Um, specifically, U S Treasury bonds. Full faith and credit, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Historically, the safe haven par excellence was the United States, in the form of Treasury bonds backed by the full faith and credit of the US government.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! The article even references an investment strategist back in 2012 saying, "When people are worried, all roads lead to Treasuries." We saw it in 2008, even though the U.S. was the epicenter of the crisis, capital *flooded* in.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! The article even references an investment strategist back in twenty twelve saying, When people are worried, all roads lead to Treasuries. We saw it in two thousand eight, even though the U S was the epicenter of the crisis, capital flooded in.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As one investment strategist put it back in 2012, When people are worried, all road lead to Treasuries. The bursting of the US real-estate bubble in 2007 offers a case in point. No one doubted that the US was the epicenter of the global financial crisis. But rather than flee the US, capital actually flooded into it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, half a trillion dollars in just three months, which is wild when you think about it. People needed dollars, but a lot of it was just, uh, sheer fear.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, half a trillion dollars in just three months, which is wild when you think about it. People needed dollars, but a lot of it was just, uh, sheer fear.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the last three months of 2008, net purchases of US assets reached a half-trillion dollars three times more than that of the preceding nine months combined. ... Much of the increased demand was due to sheer fear.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. But, um, that confidence seems to be, well, eroding a bit now. The article points to President Trump, undermining that trust.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. But, um, that confidence seems to be, well, eroding a bit now. The article points to President Trump, undermining that trust.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But this was before the arrival US President Donald Trump, who has managed to undermine confidence in the dollar to an unprecedented degree.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Abandoning fiscal responsibility, picking fights with allies... [interrupts] And honestly, it's not just Trump, right? Remember the S&P downgrade in 2011 because of the debt ceiling standoff?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Abandoning fiscal responsibility, picking fights with allies... And honestly, it's not just Trump, right? Remember the S and P downgrade in twenty eleven because of the debt ceiling standoff?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In addition to abandoning any notion of fiscal responsibility, Trump has spent his first two years in office attacking international institutions and picking fights with US allies. To be sure, even before Trump, confidence in the dollar suffered a blow in 2011, when Standard & Poors downgraded Treasury securities by one notch in response to a near-shutdown of the US government. That episode was triggered by a standoff between then-President Barack Obama and congressional Republicans over a routine proposal to raise the federal debt ceiling.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, definitely! But now, with, uh, multiple government shutdowns under Trump, like, *three* in 2018 alone, it's a constant worry for investors. So, if not the U.S., where do you even go?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, definitely! But now, with, uh, multiple government shutdowns under Trump, like, three in twenty eighteen alone, it's a constant worry for investors. So, if not the U S, where do you even go?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2018 alone, the US government was shut down three times, and it remains in a partial shutdown to this day, owing to Trumps demand for funds to build a big, beautiful wall on the border with Mexico.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Good question. The Eurozone seems like the logical next step, doesn't it? Second most-used currency, similar market size to the U.S.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Good question. The Eurozone seems like the logical next step, doesn't it? Second most-used currency, similar market size to the U S.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The eurozone might seem like a logical alternative. After the dollar, the euro is the worlds most widely used currency. And, taken together, the capital markets of the eurozones 19 member states are close in size to the US market.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: You'd think so, but, um, slowing economic growth, especially in Germany, and then the looming banking crisis in Italy... Plus, Brexit's a huge wild card. That rules out the UK entirely for now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You'd think so, but, um, slowing economic growth, especially in Germany, and then the looming banking crisis in Italy... Plus, Brexit's a huge wild card. That rules out the U K entirely for now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But Europe has troubles of its own. Economic growth is slowing, not least in Germany, and the risk of a banking crisis in Italy the eurozones fourth-largest economy looms on the horizon. Worse still is the uncertainty over Brexit, which could prove highly disruptive if the United Kingdom crashes out of the European Union without a divorce agreement. Needless to say, Britain, too, can be ruled out as a safe haven, at least until the Brexit fiasco is resolved.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the Brexit fiasco is just a mess. What about the Swiss franc? That's always seen as a safe bet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the Brexit fiasco is just a mess. What about the Swiss franc? That's always seen as a safe bet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Attractive, sure, but the markets are just too small to be a real substitute for the U.S. Then there's Japan. Huge market for government debt.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Attractive, sure, but the markets are just too small to be a real substitute for the U S. Then there's Japan. Huge market for government debt.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though its attractions are obvious, Switzerlands financial markets are simply too small to serve as an adequate substitute for the US. That leaves Japan. With its abundant supply of government bonds, it is the biggest single market for public debt outside the US.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But their debt-to-GDP is, like, 230%? Ours is 88%, even Italy's is 130%. That's just... staggering. Who's going to service that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But their debt-to-G D P is, like, two hundred thirty percent? Ours is eighty eight percent, even Italy's is one hundred thirty percent. That's just... staggering. Who's going to service that?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The question for portfolio managers, though, is whether it is really safe to invest in a country where government debt exceeds 230% of GDP. For comparison, the public debt-to-GDP ratio in the US is around 88%; and even in troubled Italy, it is no more than 130%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And China, with its huge market, is just too tightly controlled. It's the opposite of a safe haven, really.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And China, with its huge market, is just too tightly controlled. It's the opposite of a safe haven, really.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the Chinese market is so tightly controlled that it is essentially the opposite of a safe haven.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, it sounds like, um, secure ports are getting really scarce for investors.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it sounds like, um, secure ports are getting really scarce for investors.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With secure ports becoming scarce, investors will become increasingly jittery.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. Get ready for more jittery markets and, unfortunately, a lot more volatility. This "rough patch" might just be, uh, here to stay.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. Get ready for more jittery markets and, unfortunately, a lot more volatility. This rough patch might just be, uh, here to stay.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: They will be inclined to move funds at the slightest sign of danger, which will add substantially to market volatility. Todays rough patch is probably here to stay.
